originalTitle: Kenyans drop flowers for Valentine's bouquets of cash. Not everyone is impressed
title: Kenyans drop flowers for Valentine's bouquets of cash. Not everyone is impressed
content: Bouquets of cash have been blooming in popularity in Kenya but recent warnings may slow the trend.

originalTitle: Planned US-funded baby vaccine trial in Guinea-Bissau blasted by WHO
title: Fairness First! Big Doctors Say 'No!' to Unfair Baby Test in Africa!
content:
Hello from Africa!

Hello, amazing friends! It's your friendly news reporter here, bringing you important news from our wonderful continent, Africa. Today, we're going to talk about something very important for tiny babies in a country called Guinea-Bissau. It's about being fair and keeping everyone healthy! Guinea-Bissau is a beautiful country in West Africa. It has sunny beaches and lovely people. But sometimes, people there get sick, just like everywhere else in the world.

What is Hepatitis B?

Imagine there's a tiny, sneaky germ that wants to make you sick. This germ is called Hepatitis B. It's a kind of sickness that can make a part of your body called your liver very, very poorly. Your liver is super important! It helps your body clean your blood and gives you energy. When a tiny baby gets Hepatitis B, it can be very serious. They might not look sick right away, but the germ can stay in their body for a long, long time and cause big problems later. Did you know? Your liver is about the size of a football in a grown-up! It works super hard all day long to keep you healthy.

What is a Vaccine?

Luckily, there's a special kind of medicine called a vaccine! You can think of a vaccine like a superhero shield, or like a training lesson for your body. When you get a vaccine, your body learns how to fight off those sneaky germs before they can make you sick. Many babies around the world get a vaccine for Hepatitis B soon after they are born. This helps them stay strong and healthy right from the start of their lives. It's like giving them a superpower to fight off that germ! Did you know? Vaccines have helped stop many bad sicknesses around the world, like polio and measles. They help millions of kids stay safe!

The Idea for a Test

So, there was an idea from a group in America (the 'US-funded' part) to do a special test in Guinea-Bissau. They wanted to give some of the newborn babies the Hepatitis B vaccine. This vaccine is not new; it's a treatment that we know works very well to keep babies safe. They wanted to see if giving the vaccine in a certain way would be even better. But here's where the big problem started.

The Big Problem: Not Fair!

This special test had a plan that made many big doctors and health experts very worried. The plan was to give the Hepatitis B vaccine to *some* of the newborn babies in Guinea-Bissau, but *not others*. It's like if your teacher gave some kids a yummy treat but left other kids out, even if everyone loves treats! Giving a medicine that we *know* works very well to only *some* babies, and holding it back from others who need it, is called 'unethical'. That's a big word, but it just means 'not fair' or 'not right'. Did you know? Being fair means treating everyone equally and giving them the same chances, especially when it comes to being healthy and safe.

Who is the WHO?

There's a very important group called the WHO. That stands for the World Health Organization. Imagine them as a giant team of super doctors and nurses from all over the world. Their job is to help everyone on our planet stay healthy and to make sure health rules are fair. The WHO looked at this plan for the babies in Guinea-Bissau. And they said, "No! This is not fair!" They said it was 'unethical' because all babies deserve the chance to be healthy, especially when there's a safe medicine ready to help them. Did you know? The WHO works with almost every country in the world! They help with everything from stopping new sicknesses to making sure everyone has clean water.

Why is it Not Fair for Babies?

Babies are super tiny and cannot speak for themselves. They rely on grown-ups to make sure they are safe and looked after. If a vaccine is known to keep babies safe from a serious sickness like Hepatitis B, then every baby should get it if they need it. It would be unfair to put some babies at risk by not giving them a vaccine that we know can protect them. Every little baby, no matter where they are born in the world, deserves the best start in life.

What Should Happen Instead?

The big doctors at WHO said that if a vaccine is already known to work, then everyone who needs it should get it. They said that tests should only try new medicines that we don't know much about yet, or compare different ways to give a medicine, but always making sure everyone stays safe. If we want to help babies in Guinea-Bissau, the best thing to do is make sure all newborns get the Hepatitis B vaccine to protect them. That's the fair and healthy way! Did you know? There are strict rules all over the world to make sure that medical tests are done in a fair and safe way. This is to protect everyone, especially children.

Why Vaccines Are Super Important!

Vaccines are amazing! They are one of the best ways we have to keep ourselves and our communities healthy. They stop nasty germs from spreading and making lots of people sick. When many people get vaccinated, it's like building a strong, invisible wall of protection around everyone. This is called 'herd immunity', and it helps protect even those who are too tiny or too sick to get a vaccine. Did you know? Africa is working very hard to give more vaccines to children everywhere. We want all our African children to grow up strong and healthy!

Keeping Our African Babies Safe and Fair!

So, this story reminds us how important it is to always be fair, especially when it comes to keeping children healthy. The WHO spoke up for the babies of Guinea-Bissau, saying that fairness comes first. We all want every baby in Africa and around the world to have the best chance to grow up strong, happy, and healthy. And sometimes, standing up for fairness is the best way to make that happen. Keep smiling, and stay healthy, my friends!
summary: Big doctors from the World Health Organization (WHO) said 'no' to a plan to test a baby vaccine in Guinea-Bissau because it was unfair to give the Hepatitis B vaccine to only some newborns and not others, even though the vaccine is known to work and keep babies healthy.
whyMatters: This is important because all babies, no matter where they live, deserve to be treated fairly and have the best chance to be healthy, especially when there is a safe medicine that can protect them from sickness.
